Key Laboratory of Materials Physics, Institute of Solid State Physics, Chinese Academy of Sciences, Hefei 230031, People's Republic of China
College of Physics and Electronic Information, Yan'an University, Yan'an 716000, People's Republic of China
100 nm were prepared by the Pechini method
using lithium carbonate, bismuth nitrate, and lanthanum nitrate as precursors, and high density Li
ceramics were synthesized at 1023 K from these powders. The lowest temperature to synthesize the pure
phase is only 923 K by the Pechini method, 125 K lower than that in the solid state
reaction method, and the reaction time in the Pechini method (~5 h) is much shorter than that in the solid
state reaction route (~48 h). The total (bulk plus grain boundary) conductivity of polycrystalline Li
ceramics prepared by the Pechini method was as high as 2.410
S/cm at room temperature with an
activation energy of 0.40 eV. The Li
compounds were chemically stable against the widely used
up to 873 K but not chemically stable against the LiMn
Metal oxide materials showing high lithium ionic conduction are
particularly attractive in recent years owing to their potential
applications as solid electrolytes in lithium ionic secondary battery
. So far, fast lithium ionic conduction
has been reported in a wide range of materials, such as Li
. Among the above mentioned lithium electrolytes, perovskite-
type LLT had been recognized as one of the best conductors exhibiting
a bulk lithium ionic conductivity over 110
energy of 0.4 eV and a total (bulk plus grain boundary) conductivity of
ionic conductivity at room temperature as high as 10
realized in several systems, for example NASICON-type Li
stability limits the actual application of such highly conductive
to be a novel class of fast lithium ionic conductors
high lithium ionic conductivity and chemical inertness versus Li,
making them promising for application as electrolyte in all solid state
lithium secondary batteries. Among these garnet-like lithium electro-
lytes, the bismuth containing compound was noted to have the
ture with a low activation energy of 0.49 eV (from 22 C to 100 C),
which was attributed to the largest cell parameter compared with the
Generally, there are two ways to synthesize the metal oxide
lithium electrolytes: one is the conventional solid state reaction from
mixtures of oxide, carbonate, hydroxide, etc; the other is the sol
method based on hydrolysis and condensation of alkoxide and nitrate.
In the solid state reaction routes, relatively high reaction temperature
and long reaction time are necessary. Taking Li
as an example, the reported lowest synthesis temperature is
about 1048 K and the reaction time at such high temperature is as
long as 48 h. In such astringent synthesis conditions it is dif
control the chemical stoichiometry of Li
to the volatile loss of lithium and bismuth components.
gel synthesis route however, the synthesis temperature
and reaction time are much lower and shorter than in the solid state
reaction method, respectively, since the starting materials can be
mixed at the atomic or molecular level. Moreover, uniform particle
size distribution and small particle size at the nanometer level will
obviously enhance the sintering activity of the powders and therefore
increase the bulk density of the ceramics. Owing to such evident
gel method has been widely used to prepare
series are unexceptionally synthesized by the conventional solid state
In the present investigation, the nanocrystalline Li
powders were synthesized by the Pechini method using the metal
inorganic salts as chemical precursors, deionized water as solvent,
see front matter 2010 Elsevier B.V. All rights reserved.
citric acid as chelating agent, and polyethylene glycol as surface active
agent, respectively. The electrical property of the bulk Li
ceramics and the chemical compatibility between nanocrystalline
powders and the widely used cathode materials (LiCoO
was prepared in open air with analytical reagents
The amount of the selected chemical precursors was weighted in
molar ratio of the components of Li
In the synthesis process of Li
rstly dissolved in nitric acid to prepare lithium nitrate and then the
deionized water was introduced to prepare transparent solution
under vigorous stirring. Then the corresponding amount of La
O was poured into the above solution and citric acid
(designated as CA) was added at a molar ratio of CA: cationic ion
as well as the subsequently added
)=1:1 to avoid precipitation and to chelate cationic ions
After that, the corresponding molar mass of Bi(NO
into the above mixed solution and an appropriated amount of
polyethylene glycol (designated as PEG) was added as surface active
agent. The pH value of the solution was maintained at a constant value
of 0.5 by dripping nitric acid in time. The solution was stirred
vigorously at 333 K until a transparent gel was formed. The
yellow gel was heated at 373 K for 12 h and then calcined between
873 K and 973 K for 5 h to obtain pure phase Li
To prepare bulk ceramic samples for electrical conductivity
ciently ground in an agate mortar and then pressed into pellets
at an isostatic pressure of 300 MPa. Dense Li
1.2 mm in thickness and 8.2 mm in diameter) were obtained by
sintering the pressed pellets at 1023 K in air for 5 h.
The decomposition behavior of gels dried at 373 K for 12 h was
monitored on a thermo-gravimetric analyzer (Pyris 1 TGA, Perkin-
Elmer) in air with a heating rate of 10 K/min. The powder X-ray
diffraction (XRD) patterns were recorded on a
temperature in a scanning range from 10 to 80 with a step of 0.033.
nement was done using the Fullprof suite of Rietveld
software, in which the pseudo-Voigt function was used as the pro
function. The surface morphology of powders calcined at different
temperatures and the bulk ceramic was characterized by
emission scanning electron microscope (FESEM, Sirion 200, FEI).
Impedance spectra of the bulk Li
temperatures were isothermally collected in air on a computer-
controlled frequency response analyzer (Hioki 3531 Z-Hitester) in the
range of 42 Hz to 5 MHz. The amplitude of the applied voltage is 0.5 V.
xed to the both sides of wafer-
ring the silver paste at 600 C for 1 h. Prior to each
measurement, the sample was stabilized at a given temperature for at
least 30 min to ensure thermal equilibrium.
by examining the phase composition after the 1:1 wt.% mixed
powders were heated between 573 K and 873 K for 24 h in air. In
gel method, as described in Refs.
to heating treatment, the mixture of the cathode powders and
powders were ball-milled with zirconia balls in ethanol
for 12 h in order to completely mix the powders.
shows the TGA curve and the corresponding derivative
red in air with a heating rate of 10 K/min in
973 K. There are several weight loss
curve. In the relatively low temperature range of 320
is a small weight loss (~2%) that can be attributed to the
evaporation of remaining water. In the temperature range of
780 K, the largest step located around 500 K and several small
steps at higher temperature appear, representing a total weight
loss of 49%, which can be assigned to the volatile loss of the
organic solvent and the decomposition of the polymer. The last
step with 8% weight loss in the temperature range of 780
may originate from the elimination of the residual carbon, as
. This indicates that the gel must be
calcined at above 920 K to completely remove the impurity

gels obtained in air with a
precursors calcined at 873 K, 923 K and
973 K, respectively and the pattern of Li
Y.X. Gao et al. / Solid State Ionics 181 (2010) 1415
represents the powder XRD patterns of dry gels calcined at
873, 923, and 973 K for 5 h, respectively. For the Li
precursor heated at 873 K, the XRD pattern exhibits complex La
based intermediate phases. Once the calcination temperature reaches
923 K or higher, typical pure garnet-like Li
observed, and no other impurity phases are detected. This indicates
that the precursor has been fully transformed into garnet-like
phase after calcination at 923 K. After the powders
calcined at 1023 K for 5 h, a single garnet-like phase can be still
Compared with the lowest synthesis temperature of 1048 K
necessary to obtain a pure Li
, the lowest synthesis temperature of the pure
phase is only 923 K by the Pechini method,
125 K lower than that in the solid state reaction method. Moreover,
the sintering time in the Pechini method (~5 h) is much shorter than
that in the solid state reaction route (~48 h). The lower sintering
temperature and shorter sintering time in the Pechini method will be
cial to avoid the volatile loss of Li- and Bi-based components
and thus to accurately control the stoichiometry of the Li

determined by impedance spectroscopy. The complex impedance

spectrum, only one semicircle at a higher frequency regime and an

Observed (circles), calculated (line) and difference of powder X-ray diffraction
nanocrystalline powders synthesized by the Pechini
powders calcined in air for 5 h at (a) 923 K and (b) 973 K, and the SEM graphs of Li

Y.X. Gao et al. / Solid State Ionics 181 (2010) 1415
prepared by the conventional solid state reaction method (termed as
Carefully analyzing the impedance spectra, the higher frequency
semicircle is slightly pressed in fact, implying that both the bulk and
grain-boundary resistances contribute to the impedance plots. But in
the spectra, no obviously separated grain-boundary semicircle is
observed, which reveals that the grain-boundary contribution to the
total resistance should be low in comparison with bulk contribution.
Considering the large uncertainty of separating the bulk contribution
and the grain-boundary contribution from total conductivity, the total
sum of the bulk and grain-boundary contributions is therefore used to
evaluate the conduction properties of Li
Namely, in the following simulation of impedance spectra recorded
at different temperatures, the total resistance values, including bulk
resistance and grain-boundary resistance, were determined by using a
t the high-frequency arc and a CPE element
t the low frequency tail of the impedance diagram, as described in
As well known, the characteristic magnitudes of the capacitances
for the bulk, grain boundary and electrode conductions were found to
tting value of capacitance for the tail
the reasonable range of electrode capacitance. Therefore the
appearance of the tail at lower frequency may be owing to the
polarized phenomena associated with the lithium ion conduction
across the electrolyte/electrode boundary, as reported in
While for the high-frequency semicircle, the magnitudes of the
capacitance is in the order of 10
F, which can be considered as an
average of the capacitances for the bulk and grain boundary
F), and indicates from another aspect
that the high-frequency semicircle should be associated with both
contribution of the bulk and grain boundary.

0.40 eV, which is lower than the reported value of 0.49 eV in the SS
conduction properties in the PM Li
higher conductivity and lower activation energy, may be attributed to
the excellent sintering activity of nanocrystalline powders as well as
the accurate control of stoichiometry. In the SS Li
compounds, the existence of obvious pores in the SEM images
evidences that the density of the sample is actually low. The poor
sintering activity thus leads to appreciable grain-boundary contribu-
tion to the total resistance, as evidenced by the two obviously
separated bulk and grain-boundary semicircles in the impedance
. In the Pechini method however, the high density of the
sample reduces the grain-boundary contribution, and therefore
From the viewpoint of application, polycrystalline materials are
being generally used for practical application, the existence of large
grain-boundary resistances is obviously not good to improve the
conduction property of the electrolytes. For instance, the grain-
boundary contribution to the total (bulk plus grain boundary)
resistance is as high as 54% for the SS Li
result evidences from another side that the Pechini method reported
in this paper provides a useful way to prepare Li
possessing high density and good conductivity.
As well known, lithium containing transition metal oxides, such as
, are the typical positive cathode materials for the
is the most widely used cathode materials owing
to its high structural stability and excellent cycling behavior. The
is considered as another available cathode

Pechini method. The lowest calcination temperature to get a pure

cial for application of the PM
lithium ionic conductors as solid electrolytes in all-
